Chapter: 2. Introduction: Credibility, models, and parameters. Strongly recommended article: [Bayesian data analysis for newcomers](https://link.springer.com/article/10.3758/s13423-017-1272-1)
3. The R programming language. Instructions for installation of software are [here](https://sites.google.com/site/doingbayesiandataanalysis/software-installation)
4. Probability.
5. Bayes rule.
6. Inferring a probability via mathematical analysis.
7. Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC).
8. JAGS.
8, continued.
9. Hierarchical (a.k.a. multi-level) models.
9, continued. 10. Model comparison.
10, continued. 11. Null hypothesis significance testing (NHST). Strongly recommended article: [The Bayesian New Statistics](https://link.springer.com/article/10.3758/s13423-016-1221-4)
11. NHST, continued.

12. Bayesian null assessment. Strongly recommended article: [Rejecting or accepting paramter values in Bayesian estimation](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/2515245918771304) and its [important supplement](https://osf.io/fchdr/).
12, continued.
13. Goals, power, and sample size. See also [this video](http://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL_mlm7M63Y7j641Y7QJG3TfSxeZMGOsQ4).
13, continued.
15. The generalized linear model. 16. Metric predicted variable, 1 or 2 group predictor variable.
16, continued. Also power analysis applied to two groups. See article, [Bayesian estimation supersedes the t test](../../BEST/index.html).
